title: WCAS POLI_SCI 390-0-20 Special Topics in Political Science

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Prof. Jaime Dominguez Latino Politics, Winter 2016
This course will explore these implications and the histories including the more contemporary social and political developments of Latino communities in the United States from a comparative urban framework. We will focus on the diverse experiences of America's three largest groups of Latino-origin: Mexican Americans, Puerto Ricans, and
Cuban Americans.
The first part of the course will examine the social construction of Latino identities and trace the historical experiences of all three groups, comparing the elements behind each group's migration and how those processes affect their incorporation in mainstream
society. We also examine demographic resources and the impact of social capital on the political behavior of the Latino collectivity. Next, we turn to the development of a Latino politics, placing special emphasis on political attitudes, mobilization strategies and electoral participation. Lastly, we tackle public policy issues such as voting rights and language
policy. The question that we will return to throughout the course is the degree to which and under what circumstances is it appropriate to speak of a Latino community.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
1. To introduce students to the notion of Hispanic versus Latino.
2. To learn to distinguish under what conditions the above notion's take form in the political arena
3. To learn to differentiate between a racial group and an ethnic group and why it matters in the case of Latinos/Hispanics.
4. To better understand why some Latino groups compared to other have different levels of political power
5. How the immigration experiences of each Latino group impact identity formation in political, economic and social circles.
6. The better understand the structural and institutional mechanisms that give rise to Latino political agency.
7. To assess how regional variation, i.e., the Southwest versus the Midwest region, affects the politics of these communities.
8. To better assess whether Latino politics is a national, state or local phenomenon.
